betterquesting:10.desc:8:
A relic. A living relic. 
And a new ally.
The Time Lords, the long-gone people of Gallifrey were not too dissimilar from the Arbiter's civilization in Lyndenwyrm.
Shining bright, they formed relationships with many other powerful people, including the bees, with whom they formed long standing relationships.
No, not long standing, everlasting, even so long after their fall. A trust, and an admiration spanning for millenia. For their sacrifice was too great for their story to remain untold. A story, that the bees are now willing to share with me. 
And with the story, an admonition.
Power alone, ironically, holds little power. It has not been uncommon in the Universe's history that Fractallites abandoned their mission. The Soul Fiend, Xxeus, the Meatball Man, why did they rebel? Why would someone granted kinship with the Infinite and up forsaking it?
That answer, the Time Lords' fall says, is the impetus of mortality, the presumption, born from finiteness, that seeking Infinity will ultimately answer all of our question, that it will bring us peace. 
Sitting at the top of the Universe, alas, is not enough for our endless thirst. Whether it be knowledge, love, time, pleasure, we always desire more; yes, even when Infinity calls.
The fall of the Time Lords, their sacrifice, is one born from unquiet desire, a thrirst so strong to bring one of its members to madness. A madness that, coupled with the knowledge and power of an Ascended people, led to a confrontation that could only end one way. Mutual annhilation.
That is the impetus of Worthiness that permeates Gallifrey. The deity of the Gallifreyan tribes, the second sun, come after their fall. The will of the Time Lords, made recursion, lives on, and calls all who hold power to look inward, to become aware of their desire, to acknowledge their humanity, and to reconcile themselves with Infinity.
